'White people shoot at us': Southern Brazil's Indigenous communities fight for ancestral land
subhead: In Mato Grosso do Sul, a southern state bordering Paraguay, Indigenous people who tried to reclaim the lands from which they had been dispossessed face violence from large landowners. The left-wing government largely remains powerless in the face of this tragedy.

headline: Customs duties: The EU further abandons its Green Deal with pledge to buy US energy
Ukraine to 'fix' anti-graft law, says foreign minister ahead of vote
Canada says it plans to recognize the State of Palestine in September
subhead: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney said the decision to recognize Palestinian statehood at the UN in September, which aligns it with France and the UK, was motivated by its long support for the two-state solution.

headline: Journalists in the West Bank face mounting suppression
subhead: Since October 7, Israel has arrested and imprisoned at least 140 journalists working in this occupied territory, most often under the catch-all charge of 'incitement to terrorism.' The Palestinian Journalists Syndicate has condemned what it describes as a strategy to 'silence' media professionals.

headline: After Stephen Colbert's show is canceled, comedians unite against Trump
subhead: CBS has decided to end the 'Late Show', a satirical program whose host regularly skewers the US president, citing 'financial reasons.'

headline: Gabriel Hagai, a mystic and political rabbi
subhead: Hagai, 57, has lived a thousand lives. A specialist in Hebrew manuscripts, the religious figure who embraces mystical Judaism has also been a baker in Boston, a researcher and, currently, a herbalist.

'I learned freedom at 34, and it was a revelation': Katja Lange-Müller, an eastern wind blows through West Berlin
subhead: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (3/6). Katja Lange-Müller, born in the German Democratic Republic (GDR), managed as an adult to cross 'to the other side' of the Wall, escaping her mother, a prominent member of the communist regime.

headline: Economist Dmitry Nekrasov: 'Only a handful of sanctions have had a serious effect on Putin's ability to continue the war'
subhead: Nekrasov, a former Kremlin adviser who joined the opposition and now lives in exile, discusses the EU's latest package of sanctions against Russia and their potential effectiveness.

headline: 'In the West Berlin squats, we argued but lived together': Karin Wieland, political rebel
subhead: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (2/6). In the late 1970s, Karin Wieland fled her small German town to live communally in an abandoned building in Kreuzberg, throwing herself into every cause of the era.
